meta.title: Weapons Classification Assistant
meta.subtitle: Based on the ARES Arms & Munitions Classification System (ARCS)

start.question: What class of item are you looking at?
start.help: First, determine the broad class. Small arms are man-portable firearms under 20 mm calibre operated by one person. Light weapons are larger systems that may require a crew of up to five.

options.label: Small Arm
options.description: A firearm of less than 20 mm calibre that can be transported and operated by a single individual on foot.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.1_Typical features of a modern military rifle.png

options.label: Light Weapon
options.description: A lethal weapon or weapon system transportable and operable by a crew of up to five individuals, weighing 300 kg or less in firing configuration.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Box_5.2_Myths and misconceptions _rocket launchers_ versus _recoilless weapons.png

options.label: Ammunition / Munition
options.description: A cartridge, projectile, rocket, missile, grenade, or other munition for small arms or light weapons.

sa_group.question: Is the item a handgun or a long gun?
sa_group.help: Handguns are designed to be held and fired with one or two hands, without bracing against the shoulder. Long guns have a stock or butt designed to be braced against the shoulder.

options.label: Handgun
options.description: A firearm designed to be held and fired with one or two hands, without being braced against the shoulder.

options.label: Long Gun
options.description: A firearm with a stock or butt designed to be braced against the shoulder when firing.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.1_Typical features of a modern military rifle.png

sa_handgun_bore.question: Is the handgun rifled or smooth-bore?
sa_handgun_bore.help: Look at the inside of the barrel (the bore). Rifled barrels have spiral grooves; smooth-bore barrels are smooth inside. The vast majority of handguns are rifled.

options.label: Rifled
options.description: The barrel has spiral grooves (rifling) inside. This is by far the most common type.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.5_Conventional grooved rifling (left) and octagonal polygonal rifling (r.png

options.label: Smooth-bore
options.description: The barrel is smooth inside with no rifling. Uncommon in modern handguns.

sa_handgun_rifled_type.question: What type of action does the handgun have?
sa_handgun_rifled_type.help: Self-loading pistols use the energy of firing to chamber the next round and typically have a detachable box magazine in the grip. Revolvers have a rotating cylinder holding multiple cartridges. Manually-operated handguns include single-shot pistols, derringers, and other designs.

options.label: Self-loading Pistol
options.description: Uses energy from firing to cycle the action. Usually has a slide on top and a detachable magazine in the grip.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.6_Typical arrangement of a modern self-loading pistol, showing some inte.png

options.label: Revolver
options.description: Has a rotating cylinder containing multiple chambers, each holding one cartridge.

options.label: Other Manually-operated Handgun
options.description: Single-shot pistols, derringers, bolt-action pistols, and other manually-operated designs.

sa_longgun_bore.question: Is the long gun rifled or smooth-bore?
sa_longgun_bore.help: Rifled long guns (rifles, sub-machine guns, machine guns) have spiral grooves in the barrel. Smooth-bore long guns (typically shotguns) have a smooth barrel interior. Most military-style long guns are rifled.

options.label: Rifled
options.description: The barrel has spiral grooves (rifling). Includes rifles, sub-machine guns, and machine guns.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.5_Conventional grooved rifling (left) and octagonal polygonal rifling (r.png

options.label: Smooth-bore
options.description: The barrel is smooth inside. Typically a shotgun or other smooth-bore weapon.

sa_longgun_rifled_type.question: What type of rifled long gun is it?
sa_longgun_rifled_type.help: Consider the weapon's size, its ammunition type, and its intended role. Sub-machine guns fire pistol-calibre ammunition. Rifles fire rifle-calibre ammunition and are the primary individual weapon. Machine guns are designed for sustained automatic fire.

options.label: Sub-machine Gun (SMG)
options.description: A self-loading long gun chambered for pistol-calibre ammunition, typically capable of automatic fire. Usually compact.

options.label: Self-loading Rifle
options.description: A rifle that uses the energy of firing to cycle the action. Includes assault rifles, battle rifles, designated marksman rifles, and semi-automatic-only rifles.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.9_Typical features of a modern military rifle.png

options.label: Manually-operated Rifle
options.description: A rifle requiring manual action to cycle (bolt-action, lever-action, etc.). Includes sniper rifles, sporting rifles, and older military designs.

options.label: Machine Gun
options.description: Designed for sustained automatic fire, often from a bipod or tripod. Includes light machine guns (LMGs), general-purpose machine guns (GPMGs), and medium machine guns (MMGs).

sa_selfloading_rifle_subtype.question: Can you further classify the self-loading rifle's operating type?
sa_selfloading_rifle_subtype.help: If the rifle is capable of automatic fire (holding the trigger fires continuously), it is an automatic self-loading rifle. If it fires only one shot per trigger pull, it is semi-automatic only. If you are unsure, select 'Unsure / Cannot determine'.

options.label: Automatic (select-fire)
options.description: Capable of both semi-automatic and automatic fire. A fire selector switch is usually present. This category includes what are commonly called 'assault rifles' (intermediate calibre) and 'battle rifles' (full-power calibre).
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.9_Typical features of a modern military rifle.png

options.label: Semi-automatic Only
options.description: Fires only one shot per trigger pull. No automatic fire capability. Includes many civilian rifles, some military marksman rifles.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_3.1_Typical features of a modern military rifle.png

options.label: Unsure / Cannot determine
options.description: You cannot tell whether the rifle has automatic fire capability.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_1.3_Selected markings on a Heckler & Koch HK417 self-loading rifle.png

sa_machinegun_subtype.question: What category of machine gun is it?
sa_machinegun_subtype.help: Light machine guns (LMGs) / squad automatic weapons (SAWs) are typically operated by one person with a bipod. General-purpose machine guns (GPMGs) can be used on a bipod or a tripod and fire full-power rifle cartridges. If you're unsure, select the general option.

options.label: Light Machine Gun (LMG) / SAW
options.description: Magazine or belt-fed, bipod-mounted, typically chambered in an intermediate or full-power rifle calibre. Operated by one individual.

options.label: General-Purpose Machine Gun (GPMG) / Medium Machine Gun (MMG)
options.description: Belt-fed, can be used from a bipod or tripod, chambered in a full-power rifle cartridge (e.g. 7.62 × 51 mm).

options.label: Unsure / General Machine Gun
options.description: You cannot determine the specific type of machine gun.

sa_longgun_smoothbore_type.question: What type of smooth-bore long gun is it?
sa_longgun_smoothbore_type.help: Most smooth-bore long guns are shotguns. Shotguns come in various action types.

options.label: Self-loading Shotgun
options.description: A shotgun that uses firing energy to cycle the action (semi-automatic or automatic).

options.label: Manually-operated Shotgun
options.description: A shotgun requiring manual action: pump-action, break-action, bolt-action, or lever-action.

options.label: Other Smooth-bore Long Gun
options.description: A smooth-bore long gun that is not a shotgun (e.g. musket, blunderbuss, or other unusual design).

lw_group.question: Is the light weapon hand-held or crew-served?
lw_group.help: Hand-held light weapons can be carried and fired by a single individual. Crew-served weapons typically require two or more people to transport and operate effectively.

options.label: Hand-held
options.description: Can be carried and operated by one person, though heavier than small arms. Includes shoulder-fired launchers, heavy machine guns, etc.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Box_5.2_Myths and misconceptions _rocket launchers_ versus _recoilless weapons.png

options.label: Crew-served
options.description: Requires a crew of two or more to transport and/or operate. Includes mortars, crew-served grenade launchers, some heavy weapon mounts.

lw_handheld_type.question: What type of hand-held light weapon is it?
lw_handheld_type.help: Consider the weapon's general form, size, and how it appears to function.

options.label: Heavy Machine Gun (HMG)
options.description: A machine gun firing cartridges of 12.7 mm or larger (up to 14.5 mm or similar), typically mounted on a tripod, vehicle, or fixed emplacement.

options.label: Light Cannon
options.description: An automatic weapon firing ammunition of at least 20 mm but less than 57 mm calibre. Often vehicle-mounted.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Table_5.2_Dominant light cannon cartridges in global military service.png

options.label: Shoulder-fired Grenade Launcher
options.description: A single-shot or repeating launcher designed to fire grenades from the shoulder. Includes RPG-7-type launchers and standalone grenade launchers.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_5.1_Some of the key physical features of grenade launcher ammunition.png

options.label: Auxiliary (Under-barrel) Grenade Launcher
options.description: A grenade launcher attached to a rifle, fired from the under-barrel position (e.g. M203, GP-25).

options.label: Recoilless Weapon
options.description: A weapon that vents propellant gases rearward to counter recoil, firing large-calibre projectiles. Often shoulder-fired or tripod-mounted.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Box_5.2_Myths and misconceptions _rocket launchers_ versus _recoilless weapons.png

options.label: Rocket Launcher
options.description: Fires unguided rockets. May be single-use (disposable) or reloadable. Distinct from recoilless weapons.

options.label: Anti-tank Guided Missile (ATGM) System
options.description: A man-portable system that fires guided missiles, typically against armoured vehicles (e.g. TOW, Konkurs, Javelin).

options.label: Man-portable Air Defence System (MANPADS)
options.description: A shoulder-fired guided missile system designed to engage aircraft (e.g. Stinger, Igla, Strela).

lw_crewserved_type.question: What type of crew-served light weapon is it?
lw_crewserved_type.help: Consider the weapon's general form and how it operates.

options.label: Crew-served Grenade Launcher (AGL)
options.description: An automatic or semi-automatic grenade launcher operated from a tripod or vehicle mount (e.g. Mk 19, AGS-17).
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Box_5.1_FCSs and airburst munitions for AGLs.png

options.label: Light or Medium Mortar
options.description: An indirect-fire weapon of less than 100 mm calibre, consisting of a tube, baseplate, and bipod (e.g. 60 mm, 81 mm, 82 mm mortars).

options.label: Other Crew-served Light Weapon
options.description: A crew-served light weapon not fitting the above categories.

ammo_group.question: What broad type of ammunition or munition is it?
ammo_group.help: Determine whether the item is a cartridge (a complete round with case, propellant, primer, and projectile), a projectile/warhead for a light weapon, or a guided/powered munition.

options.label: Small-calibre Cartridge (under 20 mm)
options.description: A complete cartridge for a small arm: pistol, rifle, shotgun, or machine gun ammunition under 20 mm calibre.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_4.2_Basic composition of a 7.62 x 39 mm cartridge.png

options.label: Medium-calibre Cartridge (20 mm to <57 mm)
options.description: A cartridge for heavy machine guns, light cannon, or automatic grenade launchers, between 20 mm and 57 mm.
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Figure_5.2_Sample markings on a Bulgarian Arsenal RLV-HEF-1 40 x 46SR mm HE-FRAG .png

options.label: Large-calibre Ammunition (57 mm+)
options.description: Ammunition of 57 mm or larger calibre, including mortar bombs and recoilless weapon projectiles.

options.label: Rocket or Guided Missile
options.description: A powered munition: an unguided rocket or a guided missile (including ATGM and MANPADS rounds).

ammo_small_cal_type.question: What type of small-calibre cartridge is it?
ammo_small_cal_type.help: Consider the overall size and shape. Pistol cartridges are shorter and often wider relative to their length. Rifle cartridges are longer with a tapered or bottlenecked case. Shotgun shells are wider and typically have a plastic or paper hull.

options.label: Pistol / Sub-machine Gun Cartridge
options.description: Short, relatively wide cartridge for handguns or sub-machine guns (e.g. 9 × 19 mm, .45 ACP, 7.62 × 25 mm).

options.label: Rifle / Machine Gun Cartridge
options.description: Longer, typically bottlenecked cartridge for rifles or machine guns (e.g. 5.56 × 45 mm, 7.62 × 39 mm, 7.62 × 51 mm).
options.image: small_arms_survey/visuals/Table_4.1_Dominant rifle and machine gun cartridges in global military service.png

options.label: Shotgun Shell
options.description: A wide cartridge with a plastic or paper hull, fired from a shotgun (e.g. 12 gauge, 20 gauge).

result_sa_selfloading_pistol.summary: You have classified this item as a **self-loading pistol** — a rifled handgun that uses the energy from firing to cycle the action, chambering the next round automatically.
result_sa_selfloading_pistol.next_steps:
To move towards **identification** (determining the make, model, and variant), examine the following:

1. **Markings**: Look for manufacturer logos, model names, calibre designations, and serial numbers — typically found on the slide, frame, or barrel.
2. **Physical features**: Note the overall size, slide shape, grip angle, magazine type, and any distinctive features (accessory rail, manual safety type, hammer vs. striker-fired).
3. **Calibre**: If marked, this narrows identification significantly. Common calibres include 9 × 19 mm, .45 ACP, .40 S&W, and 7.62 × 25 mm.
4. **Photographs**: Take clear, well-lit photos of both sides, the top/slide markings, and any serial numbers.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_revolver.summary: You have classified this item as a **revolver** — a rifled handgun with a rotating cylinder containing multiple chambers.
result_sa_revolver.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the barrel, frame, and cylinder for manufacturer, model, calibre, and serial number markings.
2. **Physical features**: Note the number of chambers, barrel length, frame size, single-action vs. double-action trigger mechanism, and any unusual features.
3. **Calibre**: Common calibres include .38 Special, .357 Magnum, .44 Magnum, and .22 LR.
4. **Photographs**: Capture both sides, the barrel markings, and the cylinder.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_manual_handgun.summary: You have classified this item as an **other manually-operated handgun** — a rifled handgun that is neither a self-loading pistol nor a revolver. This includes single-shot pistols, derringers, bolt-action pistols, and similar designs.
result_sa_manual_handgun.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Examine the barrel, frame, and any other surfaces for manufacturer and model information.
2. **Physical features**: Note the action type (break-action, bolt-action, etc.), barrel count, calibre, and any distinctive design features.
3. **Photographs**: Capture clear images from multiple angles.
4. **Note**: Unusual handgun designs may be improvised or craft-produced — see Chapter 6 of the SAS guide.

result_sa_smoothbore_handgun.summary: You have classified this item as a **smooth-bore handgun** — a handgun without rifling in the barrel. These are uncommon in modern use and may include flare guns adapted for other purposes, improvised weapons, or certain historical designs.
result_sa_smoothbore_handgun.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check for any manufacturer or model markings.
2. **Physical features**: Note the bore diameter, action type, and construction quality — this may help determine if the weapon is factory-made, craft-produced, or improvised.
3. **Note**: Smooth-bore handguns are rare in modern contexts. Consider whether the item may be an improvised or craft-produced weapon (see Chapter 6 of the SAS guide) or a converted blank-firing weapon.

result_sa_smg.summary: You have classified this item as a **sub-machine gun (SMG)** — a self-loading long gun chambered for pistol-calibre ammunition, typically capable of automatic fire.
result_sa_smg.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and magazine housing for manufacturer, model, and serial number markings.
2. **Physical features**: Note the overall layout (conventional, bullpup, or compact), stock type (folding, collapsible, fixed), magazine position, and barrel length.
3. **Calibre**: Common SMG calibres include 9 × 19 mm, .45 ACP, and 4.6 × 30 mm.
4. **Operating system**: Note whether it uses a simple blowback action (most common for SMGs) or a locked-breech design.
5. **Photographs**: Capture both sides, markings, and the magazine.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_auto_rifle.summary: You have classified this item as an **automatic (select-fire) self-loading rifle** — a rifle capable of both semi-automatic and automatic fire, chambered for rifle-calibre ammunition. This category includes 'assault rifles' (intermediate calibre, e.g. 5.56 × 45 mm or 7.62 × 39 mm) and 'battle rifles' (full-power calibre, e.g. 7.62 × 51 mm).
result_sa_auto_rifle.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Examine the receiver, barrel, and stock for manufacturer, model, calibre, and serial number markings. Fire selector markings can also be informative.
2. **Physical features**: Note the general configuration (AK-type, AR-type, bullpup, etc.), gas system type, stock and handguard design, magazine type, muzzle device, and barrel length.
3. **Calibre**: Key distinguishing detail. Common calibres: 5.56 × 45 mm, 7.62 × 39 mm, 5.45 × 39 mm, 7.62 × 51 mm.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, markings, fire selector, magazine, and any accessories.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_semi_rifle.summary: You have classified this item as a **semi-automatic-only self-loading rifle** — a rifle that fires one round per trigger pull using self-loading action, without automatic fire capability.
result_sa_semi_rifle.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and stock for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
2. **Physical features**: Note the general design, gas system, magazine type, and barrel length. Semi-auto-only rifles may be civilian variants of military designs (with no full-auto capability), designated marksman rifles, or purpose-built sporting/hunting rifles.
3. **Calibre**: Common calibres range widely, from 5.56 × 45 mm to 7.62 × 51 mm and many sporting calibres.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, markings, fire selector (or lack thereof), and magazine.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_selfloading_rifle_general.summary: You have classified this item as a **self-loading rifle** — but you were unable to determine whether it has automatic fire capability. This is a common situation when working from photographs or at a distance.
result_sa_selfloading_rifle_general.next_steps:
To move towards **identification** and determine fire mode:

1. **Fire selector**: Look for a selector switch — if it has positions for safe, semi, and auto/burst, it is capable of automatic fire. Pictographic markings (dot, line, spray icon) are common.
2. **Markings**: Manufacturer, model, calibre, and serial number on the receiver, barrel, and stock.
3. **Physical features**: General configuration (AK-type, AR-type, bullpup, etc.), stock, handguard, magazine, muzzle device.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, close-ups of the fire selector area, markings, and any serial numbers.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_manual_rifle.summary: You have classified this item as a **manually-operated rifle** — a rifle requiring manual action by the user to cycle the weapon (e.g. bolt-action, lever-action, or falling-block). This includes older military rifles, modern sniper/precision rifles, and sporting rifles.
result_sa_manual_rifle.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Action type**: Determine the specific manual action: bolt-action (most common), lever-action, pump-action, or other.
2. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and stock for manufacturer, model, calibre, and serial numbers.
3. **Physical features**: Note barrel length, stock material and shape, sighting system, magazine type (internal vs. detachable), and any militaria features (bayonet lug, sling swivels).
4. **Calibre**: Wide range of calibres possible. Military bolt-actions are often chambered in 7.62 × 51 mm, 7.62 × 54R mm, or older calibres like .303 British.
5. **Photographs**: Both sides, action (open if possible), markings, and stock.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

classification.type: Light Machine Gun (LMG) / Squad Automatic Weapon (SAW)

result_sa_lmg.summary: You have classified this item as a **light machine gun (LMG)** or **squad automatic weapon (SAW)** — an automatic weapon designed to be operated by a single individual, typically with a bipod, firing rifle-calibre ammunition from a magazine or belt.
result_sa_lmg.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and top cover for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
2. **Physical features**: Note the feed mechanism (belt-fed, magazine-fed, or dual-feed), barrel configuration (quick-change barrel?), bipod type, stock design, and overall layout.
3. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 5.56 × 45 mm, 5.45 × 39 mm, and 7.62 × 39 mm (for LMGs) or 7.62 × 51 mm (sometimes classified as GPMG).
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, feed mechanism, markings, bipod, and barrel.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

classification.type: General-purpose Machine Gun (GPMG) / Medium Machine Gun (MMG)

result_sa_gpmg.summary: You have classified this item as a **general-purpose machine gun (GPMG)** or **medium machine gun (MMG)** — a belt-fed automatic weapon chambered for a full-power rifle cartridge, capable of being used from a bipod or a tripod mount.
result_sa_gpmg.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, feed tray cover, and tripod/mount for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
2. **Physical features**: Note the belt-feed mechanism, barrel (quick-change capability), stock type, bipod/tripod, and overall configuration.
3. **Calibre**: Usually 7.62 × 51 mm (NATO) or 7.62 × 54R mm (Soviet/Russian). Some GPMGs fire other calibres.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, feed mechanism (open if possible), barrel, markings, and mount.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_machinegun_general.summary: You have classified this item as a **machine gun** — an automatic weapon designed for sustained fire — but the specific subtype (LMG, GPMG, etc.) could not be determined.
result_sa_machinegun_general.next_steps:
To move towards **identification** and subtype determination:

1. **Calibre**: This is often the key discriminator. LMGs/SAWs tend to fire intermediate rifle cartridges (5.56 × 45 mm, 5.45 × 39 mm), while GPMGs fire full-power cartridges (7.62 × 51 mm, 7.62 × 54R mm).
2. **Feed system**: Belt-fed, magazine-fed, or dual-feed.
3. **Markings**: Manufacturer, model, calibre, serial number.
4. **Physical features**: Bipod, tripod, barrel configuration, stock.
5. **Photographs**: Both sides, feed system, markings, and any mount.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_selfloading_shotgun.summary: You have classified this item as a **self-loading shotgun** — a smooth-bore long gun that uses firing energy to cycle the action (semi-automatic or, rarely, automatic).
result_sa_selfloading_shotgun.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check the barrel, receiver, and stock for manufacturer, model, gauge, and serial number.
2. **Physical features**: Note the gauge (12 gauge is most common), barrel length, action type (gas-operated, inertia-driven, etc.), magazine type (tubular, box, drum), and stock configuration.
3. **Photographs**: Both sides, barrel markings, receiver, and magazine/loading port.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_manual_shotgun.summary: You have classified this item as a **manually-operated shotgun** — a smooth-bore long gun requiring manual action to cycle. This includes pump-action, break-action (single and double barrel), bolt-action, and lever-action shotguns.
result_sa_manual_shotgun.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Action type**: Determine the specific action: pump-action, break-action (single barrel, side-by-side, over-and-under), bolt-action, or lever-action.
2. **Markings**: Check barrel (often marked with gauge, chamber length, and choke), receiver, and stock.
3. **Physical features**: Gauge, barrel length and configuration (single, double, etc.), stock material and design.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, barrel markings (often on the barrel flats of break-action guns), receiver, and action (open if possible).

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 3: Small Arms

result_sa_other_smoothbore.summary: You have classified this item as an **other smooth-bore long gun** — a smooth-bore weapon that is not a standard shotgun. This may include muskets, blunderbusses, improvised weapons, or other unusual designs.
result_sa_other_smoothbore.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Markings**: Check for any manufacturer, proof, or military markings.
2. **Physical features**: Note the bore diameter, action type, construction quality, and any distinctive features.
3. **Note**: Consider whether this may be an improvised, craft-produced, or historical muzzle-loading weapon — see Chapter 6 of the SAS guide.
4. **Photographs**: Multiple angles, close-ups of any markings and construction details.

result_lw_hmg.summary: You have classified this item as a **heavy machine gun (HMG)** — an automatic weapon firing cartridges of approximately 12.7 mm or larger, typically mounted on a tripod, vehicle, or emplacement.
result_lw_hmg.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre**: The most common HMG calibres are 12.7 × 99 mm (.50 BMG, used in the M2 Browning) and 12.7 × 108 mm (Soviet/Russian, used in the DShK/DShKM and NSV). 14.5 × 114 mm (KPV) is also encountered.
2. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and mount for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
3. **Physical features**: Feed mechanism, barrel configuration, mount type, and receiver shape.
4. **Photographs**: Both sides, receiver markings, barrel, feed mechanism, and mount.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_light_cannon.summary: You have classified this item as a **light cannon** — an automatic weapon firing ammunition of at least 20 mm but less than 57 mm calibre. These are typically vehicle-mounted.
result_lw_light_cannon.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 20 × 102 mm, 20 × 139 mm, 23 × 152B mm, 25 × 137 mm, and 30 × 113B mm.
2. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and any mounting hardware.
3. **Physical features**: Feed mechanism, barrel type, mounting arrangement.
4. **Photographs**: Multiple angles, markings, barrel, and feed system.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_shoulder_gl.summary: You have classified this item as a **shoulder-fired grenade launcher** — a weapon designed to fire grenades from the shoulder. This includes standalone single-shot launchers (e.g. M79, RPG-7) and multi-shot grenade launchers (e.g. RGM-40, MGL).
result_lw_shoulder_gl.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Launcher type**: Single-shot or multi-shot (revolving cylinder, pump-action, etc.).
2. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 40 × 46SR mm (low-velocity), 40 × 53SR mm (high-velocity), and various RPG calibres.
3. **Markings**: Check the barrel/tube, receiver, and sights for manufacturer and model markings.
4. **Physical features**: Barrel/tube shape, sighting system, stock configuration, and overall length.
5. **Note**: Be careful to distinguish between recoilless weapons (which use a counterbalancing gas vent) and rocket launchers — see Boxes 5.2 in the SAS guide.
6. **Photographs**: Both sides, muzzle, breech, sights, and markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_auxiliary_gl.summary: You have classified this item as an **auxiliary (under-barrel) grenade launcher** — a grenade launcher designed to be attached to a rifle and fired from the under-barrel position (e.g. M203, GP-25, AG-36).
result_lw_auxiliary_gl.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Host weapon**: Note the rifle the launcher is attached to — this often narrows down the launcher model.
2. **Calibre**: Usually 40 × 46SR mm (Western) or VOG-type 40 mm (Soviet/Russian).
3. **Markings**: Check the launcher tube/barrel and trigger assembly for markings.
4. **Physical features**: Mounting method, barrel length, trigger mechanism, and sighting system.
5. **Photographs**: The launcher from both sides (attached to the rifle), markings, and trigger mechanism.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_recoilless.summary: You have classified this item as a **recoilless weapon** — a weapon that vents propellant gases rearward to counteract recoil, allowing the firing of large-calibre projectiles from a lightweight launcher. Distinct from rocket launchers (the projectile is not self-propelled).
result_lw_recoilless.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 73 mm (SPG-9), 82 mm (B-10), 84 mm (Carl Gustaf), and 106 mm (M40).
2. **Configuration**: Shoulder-fired (e.g. Carl Gustaf) or tripod-mounted (e.g. SPG-9).
3. **Markings**: Check the tube/barrel, breech, and mount for manufacturer and model markings.
4. **Physical features**: Venturi nozzle at the rear (distinctive feature), barrel length, sighting system, and mount.
5. **Photographs**: Both sides, rear venturi, breech, sights, and markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_rocket_launcher.summary: You have classified this item as a **rocket launcher** — a weapon that fires unguided, self-propelled rockets. May be single-use (disposable, e.g. RPG-18, M72 LAW, AT4) or reloadable (e.g. RPG-7, which is technically a recoilless launcher for rocket-assisted projectiles).
result_lw_rocket_launcher.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Disposable or reloadable**: Single-use launchers are typically sealed tubes discarded after firing. Reloadable launchers have a separate rocket/projectile loaded from the front.
2. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 66 mm (M72), 72.5 mm (RPG-18/22/26), 84 mm (AT4), and various RPG projectile diameters.
3. **Markings**: Check the tube, sighting system, and any external labels.
4. **Physical features**: Tube shape, sights, trigger mechanism, and carry handle.
5. **Photographs**: Both sides, front and rear of the tube, sights, and markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_atgm.summary: You have classified this item as an **anti-tank guided missile (ATGM) system** — a man-portable system that launches guided missiles, typically designed to defeat armoured vehicles.
result_lw_atgm.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Guidance type**: Wire-guided (SACLOS), laser-guided, infrared, or fire-and-forget — this often identifies the generation and narrows down the model.
2. **Launch configuration**: Tube-launched, rail-launched, or tripod-launched.
3. **Markings**: Check the launcher, command launch unit (CLU), and missile tube/container for manufacturer, model, and lot markings.
4. **Physical features**: Launcher shape, optics/sighting unit, missile tube shape and size.
5. **Common examples**: TOW, Konkurs/Fagot, Milan, Javelin, Kornet, Metis.
6. **Photographs**: Launcher from multiple angles, optics, missile container, and all markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_manpads.summary: You have classified this item as a **man-portable air defence system (MANPADS)** — a shoulder-fired guided missile system designed to engage aircraft.
result_lw_manpads.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Seeker type**: Infrared homing (most common), laser-guided, or other — this identifies the generation.
2. **Launch configuration**: Shoulder-fired tube with attached gripstock and battery/coolant unit.
3. **Markings**: Check the launch tube, gripstock, battery/coolant unit, and missile container for markings and lot numbers.
4. **Physical features**: Tube shape and length, gripstock design, optical sight, IFF (identification friend or foe) antenna.
5. **Common examples**: Stinger (FIM-92), Igla (9K38), Strela-2/-3 (9K32/9K34).
6. **SAFETY NOTE**: MANPADS contain explosive warheads and rocket motors. Do not handle without specialist training.
7. **Photographs**: Multiple angles, gripstock, optical sight, tube markings, and battery/coolant unit.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_agl.summary: You have classified this item as a **crew-served grenade launcher**, also known as an **automatic grenade launcher (AGL)** — a belt- or magazine-fed weapon that fires grenades automatically or semi-automatically, typically from a tripod or vehicle mount.
result_lw_agl.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 30 × 29B mm (AGS-17), 40 × 53SR mm (Mk 19, HK GMG), and 35 × 32SR mm (Type 87).
2. **Feed mechanism**: Belt-fed (most common) or magazine-fed.
3. **Markings**: Check the receiver, barrel, and mount.
4. **Physical features**: Receiver shape, barrel length, feed system, sighting unit, and mount type.
5. **Photographs**: Both sides, feed mechanism, barrel, sights, mount, and markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_mortar.summary: You have classified this item as a **light or medium mortar** — an indirect-fire weapon of less than 100 mm calibre, typically consisting of a tube, baseplate, and bipod/mount.
result_lw_mortar.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre**: Common calibres include 51 mm, 60 mm (light mortars) and 81 mm / 82 mm (medium mortars).
2. **Components**: Identify the tube, baseplate, bipod, and sight unit. These are the primary components.
3. **Markings**: Check the tube (often near the muzzle or base), baseplate, and bipod for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
4. **Physical features**: Tube length, baseplate shape, bipod configuration, and sighting system.
5. **Photographs**: Assembled mortar from multiple angles, close-ups of tube markings, baseplate markings, and sight unit.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_lw_other_crewserved.summary: You have classified this item as an **other crew-served light weapon** that does not fit neatly into the mortar or AGL categories.
result_lw_other_crewserved.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **General assessment**: Determine the weapon's function — what does it fire and how?
2. **Markings**: Check all surfaces for manufacturer, model, and serial number.
3. **Physical features**: Note the overall size, weight, mounting arrangement, and firing mechanism.
4. **Photographs**: Multiple angles of all components, markings, and any serial numbers.
5. **Specialist consultation**: Consider consulting an arms specialist for unusual or unfamiliar crew-served weapons.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons

result_ammo_pistol.summary: You have classified this item as a **pistol or sub-machine gun cartridge** — small-calibre ammunition designed for handguns or sub-machine guns.
result_ammo_pistol.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Headstamp**: The markings on the base of the cartridge case are the single most important identification feature. They typically indicate the manufacturer, calibre, and year of production.
2. **Calibre measurement**: Measure the cartridge overall length and case diameter. Common calibres: 9 × 19 mm, .45 ACP, 7.62 × 25 mm, .40 S&W.
3. **Physical features**: Case shape (straight or tapered), case material (brass, steel, aluminium), projectile type (FMJ, JHP, etc.), and primer type (Berdan or Boxer).
4. **Sealants**: Note any coloured sealants around the primer or case mouth — these vary by manufacturer and origin.
5. **Packaging**: If packaging is available, photograph all markings, lot numbers, and text.
6. **Photographs**: Both sides, headstamp (well-lit close-up), overall cartridge, and any packaging.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 4: Small-calibre Ammunition

result_ammo_rifle.summary: You have classified this item as a **rifle or machine gun cartridge** — small-calibre ammunition designed for rifles or machine guns, typically with a bottlenecked case.
result_ammo_rifle.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Headstamp**: The base markings are the primary identification feature. They typically indicate manufacturer, calibre, and production year.
2. **Calibre measurement**: Key calibres include 5.56 × 45 mm, 7.62 × 39 mm, 5.45 × 39 mm, 7.62 × 51 mm, and 7.62 × 54R mm.
3. **Physical features**: Case shape (bottlenecked is standard), case material, projectile type and colour coding (may indicate functional type: ball, tracer, AP, incendiary, etc.).
4. **Projectile colour codes**: NATO and Warsaw Pact/Soviet systems use different colour coding — see the SAS guide Tables 4.4 and 4.5.
5. **Packaging**: If available, photograph all lot numbers, text, and markings.
6. **Photographs**: Headstamp close-up, full cartridge from the side, projectile tip, and any packaging.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 4: Small-calibre Ammunition

result_ammo_shotgun.summary: You have classified this item as a **shotgun shell** — ammunition with a wide-diameter hull (typically plastic or paper) designed for smooth-bore shotguns.
result_ammo_shotgun.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Headstamp/base markings**: Check the metal base for manufacturer and gauge markings.
2. **Gauge**: 12 gauge is the most common. Other gauges include 10, 16, 20, and .410 bore.
3. **Shell markings**: The hull often carries printed information including manufacturer, gauge, shot size, and shell length.
4. **Physical features**: Hull colour (varies by manufacturer and load type), crimp type (star crimp or roll crimp), and shell length.
5. **Photographs**: Base/headstamp, full shell from the side, and any printed markings on the hull.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 4: Small-calibre Ammunition

result_ammo_medium_cal.summary: You have classified this item as a **medium-calibre cartridge** — ammunition of at least 20 mm but less than 57 mm in calibre, used in heavy machine guns (≥20 mm), light cannon, and automatic grenade launchers.
result_ammo_medium_cal.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre measurement**: Common calibres include 20 × 102 mm, 20 × 139 mm, 23 × 152B mm, 25 × 137 mm, 30 × 113B mm, 30 × 165 mm, and 40 × 53SR mm (grenade).
2. **Headstamp**: Base markings indicating manufacturer, calibre, lot, and year.
3. **Projectile markings**: Colour coding and stencilled text on the projectile body indicate functional type (HE, AP, TP, etc.).
4. **Physical features**: Case type, projectile shape, fuze type (if present), driving band.
5. **Packaging**: If available, photograph all lot numbers and markings.
6. **SAFETY NOTE**: Some medium-calibre ammunition contains explosive filler. Do not handle without specialist training.
7. **Photographs**: Full cartridge, headstamp, projectile markings, and any packaging.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons Ammunition

result_ammo_large_cal.summary: You have classified this item as **large-calibre ammunition** — projectiles of 57 mm or greater calibre, including mortar bombs and recoilless weapon projectiles.
result_ammo_large_cal.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Calibre measurement**: Common calibres include 60 mm, 73 mm, 81/82 mm, and 84 mm.
2. **Type**: Mortar bomb, recoilless weapon projectile, or other.
3. **Markings**: Check the body, fuze, and fins/tail assembly for stencilled markings indicating manufacturer, model, lot, and functional type.
4. **Physical features**: Body shape, fin/tail assembly, fuze type, and driving band.
5. **SAFETY NOTE**: Large-calibre ammunition contains explosive filler and/or rocket motors. Do not handle without specialist EOD training.
6. **Photographs**: Full projectile from multiple angles, fuze, tail/fins, all markings, and any packaging.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons Ammunition

result_ammo_powered.summary: You have classified this item as a **rocket or guided missile** — a powered (self-propelled) munition. Rockets are unguided; guided missiles have a guidance system (wire, infrared, laser, etc.).
result_ammo_powered.next_steps:
To move towards **identification**:

1. **Guided or unguided**: Guided missiles typically have fins, seeker heads, or control surfaces; rockets are simpler with stabilising fins only.
2. **Type**: ATGM round, MANPADS round, unguided rocket (e.g. RPG-7 projectile, S-5 rocket), etc.
3. **Markings**: Check the body, motor section, warhead, and container/packaging for stencilled and stamped markings.
4. **Physical features**: Overall length, body diameter, warhead shape, fin configuration, seeker/guidance section.
5. **SAFETY NOTE**: Rockets and guided missiles contain explosive warheads and rocket motors. Do not handle without specialist EOD training.
6. **Photographs**: Full munition from multiple angles, warhead, motor section, fins, and all markings.

references.name: SAS Weapons ID Guide — Chapter 5: Light Weapons Ammunition
